title: Common Network Protocols and Services
description: Master common network protocols through comprehensive practice covering web protocols, email, network services, remote access, directory services, network management, file sharing, and VoIP protocols with their port numbers and security considerations.
starterCode:
# Common Network Protocols Complete Exercise - Based on Lesson 008
# Covers all major protocol categories, ports, and security

## SECTION 1: Protocol Categories Overview

# Eight main protocol categories:
# 1. Application ___: HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, SFTP, TFTP
# 2. ___: SMTP, POP3, IMAP
# 3. Network ___: DNS, DHCP, NTP
# 4. Remote ___: SSH, Telnet, RDP, VNC
# 5. ___ Services: LDAP, Kerberos
# 6. Network ___: SNMP, Syslog
# 7. File ___: SMB, NFS
# 8. Voice/___: SIP, RTP, H.323


## SECTION 2: HTTP - HyperText Transfer Protocol

# Port: ___
# Protocol: ___ (TCP/UDP)
# Security: ___ (none/encrypted)

# Characteristics:
# - Request-___ protocol
# - ___ (each request independent)
# - Methods: GET, ___, PUT, DELETE

# Status codes:
# 200: ___
# 404: Not ___
# 500: ___ Error

# When to use:
# Answer: ___ applications, development (never for ___ data)


## SECTION 3: HTTPS - HTTP Secure

# Port: ___
# Protocol: ___ (TCP/UDP)
# Security: ___/SSL encryption

# Three main benefits:
# 1. Encrypts all ___ traffic
# 2. Server ___ via certificates
# 3. Protects against ___ and tampering

# Certificate components:
# - Public ___
# - Issued to: ___ name
# - Issued by: Certificate ___ (CA)
# - Validity ___

# When to use:
# Answer: All modern ___, especially those handling ___ information


## SECTION 4: FTP - File Transfer Protocol

# Port 20: ___ connection (TCP)
# Port 21: ___ connection (TCP)
# Security: ___ (credentials and data in clear text)

# Two modes:

# Active FTP:
# - Client connects to server port ___
# - Server connects ___ to client
# - Problem: Client ___ may block incoming connection

# Passive FTP:
# - Client initiates ___ connections
# - Solution: ___-friendly

# When to use:
# Answer: ___ systems, internal networks (not secure for ___)


## SECTION 5: FTPS and SFTP

# FTPS:
# Full name: FTP ___
# Port (Implicit): ___, ___
# Port (Explicit): ___
# Security: ___/SSL encryption
# Modes: ___ or explicit

# SFTP:
# Full name: ___ File Transfer Protocol
# Port: ___
# Protocol: Runs over ___
# Security: SSH ___
# Relation to FTPS: ___ the same (not/is)
# Modern status: ___ method for secure file transfer

# Key difference:
# FTPS uses: ___ encryption
# SFTP uses: ___ encryption


## SECTION 6: TFTP - Trivial FTP

# Port: ___
# Protocol: ___ (TCP/UDP)
# Security: ___ (none/encrypted)
# Authentication: ___ (yes/no)

# Characteristics:
# - Minimal ___
# - No ___ listing
# - No ___

# Three common use cases:
# 1. Router/switch ___ backups
# 2. ___ network booting
# 3. ___ updates on embedded devices

# When to use:
# Answer: Network device configs, ___ boot, firmware updates (internal networks only)


## SECTION 7: SMTP - Simple Mail Transfer Protocol

# Port 25: ___-to-___ relay
# Port 587: Client ___ with TLS
# Protocol: ___ (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: ___ email (sending/receiving)
# Security: Optional (___ on port 587)

# SMTP process:
# Client → Mail Server (Port ___): Submit email
# Mail Server → Recipient Server (Port ___): Relay email

# Five SMTP commands:
# 1. ___: Hello
# 2. MAIL ___: Sender address
# 3. RCPT ___: Recipient address
# 4. ___: Message content
# 5. ___: End session


## SECTION 8: POP3 - Post Office Protocol v3

# Port (plain): ___
# Port (secure): ___ (POP3S)
# Purpose: ___ email from server
# Security: Optional ___/TLS

# Characteristics:
# - Download-and-___ model
# - Email ___ from server after download (typically)
# - ___-device access pattern
# - ___ protocol (simple/complex)
# - ___ folder support (limited/full)

# Five POP3 commands:
# 1. ___: Username
# 2. ___: Password
# 3. ___: List messages
# 4. ___: Retrieve message
# 5. ___: Delete message

# When to use:
# Answer: ___-device email access, offline email storage


## SECTION 9: IMAP - Internet Message Access Protocol

# Port (plain): ___
# Port (secure): ___ (IMAPS)
# Purpose: ___ email on server
# Security: Optional ___/TLS

# Characteristics:
# - Email stays on ___
# - ___-device synchronization
# - ___ management
# - Partial message ___
# - ___ capabilities
# - More ___ than POP3 (complex/simple)


## SECTION 10: IMAP vs POP3 Comparison

# Email location:
# IMAP: ___
# POP3: ___

# Multi-device support:
# IMAP: ___ (yes/no)
# POP3: ___ (yes/no)

# Folder support:
# IMAP: ___ support
# POP3: ___ support

# Storage usage:
# IMAP: ___ storage used
# POP3: ___ storage used

# Modern preference:
# Answer: ___ is preferred for modern email access


## SECTION 11: DNS - Domain Name System

# Port: ___
# Protocols: ___ for queries, ___ for zone transfers
# Purpose: Resolve domain ___ to ___ addresses
# Security: ___ available

# Characteristics:
# - ___ distributed database
# - Uses ___ to improve performance
# - Multiple ___ types


## SECTION 12: DNS Record Types

# A record:
# Maps to: ___ address (IPv4/IPv6)
# Example: example.com → ___

# AAAA record:
# Maps to: ___ address (IPv4/IPv6)
# Example: example.com → 2001:db8::1

# CNAME record:
# Purpose: Canonical name (___)
# Example: www → ___

# MX record:
# Purpose: ___ exchange
# Example: mail.example.com (priority ___)

# PTR record:
# Purpose: ___ lookup (IP to name)
# Direction: ___ DNS

# NS record:
# Purpose: Name ___

# TXT record:
# Purpose: ___ records
# Uses: ___, DKIM, domain verification


## SECTION 13: DNS Query Process

# Four steps:
# 1. Client checks local ___
# 2. Queries configured ___ server (recursive resolver)
# 3. Recursive resolver queries:
#    - ___ servers →
#    - ___ servers →
#    - ___ servers
# 4. Result ___ and returned to client


## SECTION 14: DHCP - Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol

# Port (server): ___
# Port (client): ___
# Protocol: ___ (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Automatic ___ address assignment
# Security: ___ (can be secured with DHCP snooping)

# Four things DHCP provides:
# 1. IP ___
# 2. ___ mask
# 3. Default ___
# 4. ___ servers

# Assignment type: ___-based (temporary)


## SECTION 15: DHCP DORA Process

# Step 1 - Discover:
# Client: ___ "I need an IP"
# Method: ___ (broadcast/unicast)

# Step 2 - Offer:
# Server: ___ IP address
# Method: Unicast or ___

# Step 3 - Request:
# Client: ___ offered IP
# Method: ___ (broadcast/unicast)

# Step 4 - Acknowledge:
# Server: ___ assignment
# Method: Unicast or ___


## SECTION 16: DHCP Lease Management

# Default lease time: Often ___ hours to ___ days

# Renewal timing:
# - T1: Client renews at ___% of lease time
# - T2: If renewal fails, rebinding at ___% of lease time

# Client can: ___ release IP

# Key DHCP options:
# Option 1: ___ mask
# Option 3: Default ___ (router)
# Option 6: ___ servers
# Option 66: ___ server (for PXE boot)


## SECTION 17: NTP - Network Time Protocol

# Port: ___
# Protocol: ___ (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: ___ synchronization
# Security: NTPsec, ___

# Hierarchical system:
# - Stratum ___: Reference clocks (atomic, GPS)
# - Stratum ___: Servers directly connected to Stratum 0
# - Stratum ___-15: Further downstream
# - Stratum ___: Unsynchronized

# Three reasons NTP is critical:
# 1. Log ___
# 2. ___ authentication (±5 min tolerance)
# 3. ___ validation

# Four public NTP servers:
# 1. time.___.gov
# 2. pool.___.org
# 3. time.___.com
# 4. time.___.com


## SECTION 18: SSH - Secure Shell

# Port: ___
# Protocol: ___ (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Secure ___ access and file transfer
# Security: Strong ___
# Replaces: ___ (insecure protocol)

# Three authentication methods:
# 1. ___: Username and password
# 2. Public ___: More secure, no password needed
# 3. ___: PKI-based authentication

# Four SSH uses:
# 1. Remote ___-line access
# 2. Secure file transfer (___, SCP)
# 3. Port ___ (tunneling)
# 4. Remote command ___

# Common implementations:
# - ___
# - ___


## SECTION 19: Telnet

# Port: ___
# Protocol: ___ (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Remote ___ access
# Security: ___ (all data in clear text)

# Security risk:
# - Credentials visible to packet ___
# - All data ___
# - ___ protocol

# Two valid uses:
# 1. Testing ___ connectivity (telnet host port)
# 2. ___ device management (internal networks only)

# Modern replacement:
# Answer: ___ (port ___)


## SECTION 20: RDP - Remote Desktop Protocol

# Port: ___
# Protocol: ___ (TCP/UDP)
# Vendor: ___
# Purpose: Windows remote ___ access
# Type: ___ remote control
# Security: Encryption available (___)
# Built into: ___

# Features:
# - Sound ___
# - Clipboard ___
# - Printer ___
# - ___-monitor support
# - Network Level ___ (NLA)

# Five RDP security practices:
# 1. Use Network Level ___
# 2. Enable ___ encryption
# 3. Use strong ___ or certificates
# 4. Implement account ___ policies
# 5. Consider ___ for Internet access


## SECTION 21: VNC - Virtual Network Computing

# Port: ___ + display number
# Protocol: ___ (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: ___-independent remote desktop
# Security: Usually ___ (encryption varies)

# Characteristics:
# - ___-platform (Windows, Linux, macOS)
# - Multiple ___ (RealVNC, TightVNC, etc.)
# - Generally less secure than ___
# - Can ___ over SSH for security

# Port calculation:
# Display :0 → Port ___
# Display :1 → Port ___
# Display :2 → Port ___


## SECTION 22: LDAP - Lightweight Directory Access Protocol

# Port (plain): ___
# Port (secure): ___ (LDAPS)
# Protocol: ___ (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Access and maintain ___ services
# Security: Optional ___ (LDAPS)

# Characteristics:
# - ___ directory structure
# - Used by Active ___
# - Store user ___, groups, computers
# - ___ and authorization

# LDAP structure example:
# dc=example,dc=com (___)
#   └── ou=Users (organizational ___)
#        └── cn=John Doe (common ___)

# Five LDAP operations:
# 1. ___: Authenticate
# 2. ___: Query
# 3. ___: Create entry
# 4. ___: Update entry
# 5. ___: Remove entry


## SECTION 23: Kerberos

# Port: ___
# Protocol: TCP/___ (both)
# Purpose: Network ___ protocol
# Security: Strong ___
# Used by: Active ___

# Characteristics:
# - ___-based authentication
# - Single ___-On (SSO)
# - ___ authentication (client and server verify each other)
# - Time-sensitive: Requires synchronized ___ (±___ min tolerance)

# Three Kerberos components:
# - ___: Key Distribution Center (Domain Controller)
# - ___: Ticket Granting Ticket
# - ___: Kerberos domain (EXAMPLE.COM)


## SECTION 24: Kerberos Process

# Six steps:
# 1. Client → ___: Request Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT)
# 2. KDC → Client: TGT (encrypted with user ___)
# 3. Client → KDC: Request ___ ticket using TGT
# 4. KDC → Client: ___ ticket
# 5. Client → Server: Present service ___
# 6. Server → Client: Grant ___


## SECTION 25: RADIUS

# Full name: Remote ___ Dial-In User Service
# Port (auth): ___
# Port (accounting): ___
# Protocol: ___ (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Centralized ___ (Authentication, Authorization, Accounting)
# Security: Shared ___, MD5

# Encryption:
# RADIUS encrypts: ___ only (not entire packet)

# Three common use cases:
# 1. 802.___ wireless authentication
# 2. ___ authentication
# 3. Network device ___


## SECTION 26: TACACS+

# Full name: Terminal Access Controller ___-Control System Plus
# Port: ___
# Protocol: ___ (TCP/UDP)
# Vendor: ___ (proprietary)
# Purpose: AAA protocol
# Security: Encrypts ___ packet

# Key advantage over RADIUS:
# TACACS+ encrypts: ___ packet
# RADIUS encrypts: ___ only

# Protocol reliability:
# TACACS+ uses: ___ (more reliable)
# RADIUS uses: ___ (less reliable)

# Typical use case:
# Answer: ___ network device administration


## SECTION 27: TACACS+ vs RADIUS Comparison

# Encryption:
# TACACS+: ___ packet
# RADIUS: ___ only

# Protocol:
# TACACS+: ___ (port ___)
# RADIUS: ___ (ports ___, ___)

# AAA separation:
# TACACS+: ___ (yes/no)
# RADIUS: ___ (yes/no)

# Vendor:
# TACACS+: ___ proprietary
# RADIUS: Open ___

# Best for:
# TACACS+: Device ___
# RADIUS: Network ___


## SECTION 28: SNMP - Simple Network Management Protocol

# Port (queries): ___
# Port (traps): ___
# Protocol: ___ (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Network device ___ and management
# Model: ___-agent model

# Three SNMP versions:
# SNMPv1: Original, community ___ (plain text)
# SNMPv2c: Improved performance, still community ___
# SNMPv3: ___ and encryption (use this!)

# Five SNMP operations:
# 1. ___: Retrieve single value
# 2. GET-___: Retrieve next value
# 3. GET-___: Retrieve multiple values
# 4. ___: Modify configuration
# 5. ___: Unsolicited alert from agent

# MIB:
# Full name: Management ___ Base
# Contains: Database of manageable ___
# Identifier: ___ (Object Identifier)


## SECTION 29: Syslog

# Port: ___
# Protocol: ___ (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Centralized ___
# Security: ___ (can use TLS)

# Eight severity levels (0-7):
# Level 0: ___ (system unusable)
# Level 1: ___ (immediate action required)
# Level 2: ___ (critical condition)
# Level 3: ___ (error condition)
# Level 4: ___ (warning condition)
# Level 5: ___ (normal but significant)
# Level 6: ___ (informational message)
# Level 7: ___ (debug-level message)

# Syslog message format:
# <___>Timestamp Hostname Process[PID]: Message


## SECTION 30: SMB - Server Message Block

# Port: ___
# Legacy ports: ___-139
# Protocol: ___ (TCP/UDP)
# OS: ___ file and printer sharing
# Old name: ___ (older versions)
# Security: SMB___+ encrypted

# Three SMB versions:
# SMB1: Obsolete, major ___ issues (___), disable it!
# SMB2: Windows ___+, significant improvements
# SMB3: Windows ___+, encryption, better performance

# Use:
# - Network ___ mapping (Z:)
# - ___ sharing

# Security note:
# Answer: ___ SMB1 due to security vulnerabilities


## SECTION 31: NFS - Network File System

# Port: ___
# Protocol: TCP/___ (both)
# OS: ___/Linux file sharing
# Purpose: Mount remote ___ locally
# Security: NFSv___ has Kerberos support

# Characteristics:
# - Unix/Linux ___
# - ___ file access
# - Versions: NFSv___ (common), NFSv___ (modern)

# NFS vs SMB:
# NFS: ___/Linux native
# SMB: ___ native
# Both: Can work ___-platform


## SECTION 32: SIP - Session Initiation Protocol

# Port (unencrypted): ___
# Port (encrypted): ___ (TLS)
# Protocol: UDP/___ (both)
# Purpose: ___ call setup and management
# Type: ___ protocol (not voice transport)

# Functions:
# - Call ___, modification, teardown
# - Video ___
# - Instant ___
# - Works with ___ for actual media

# Five SIP messages:
# 1. ___: Initiate call
# 2. ___: Confirm invitation
# 3. ___: End call
# 4. ___: Cancel pending invitation
# 5. ___: Register with SIP server


## SECTION 33: RTP - Real-time Transport Protocol

# Port: ___ (typically 16384-32767)
# Protocol: ___ (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: ___/video delivery
# Security: ___ (Secure RTP)

# Characteristics:
# - Delivers ___ and video streams
# - Works with ___ (signaling)
# - Low ___
# - Sequence numbers for ___
# - ___ for synchronization
# - Does not guarantee ___ (UDP)

# Relationship:
# SIP handles: ___
# RTP handles: ___ delivery


## SECTION 34: Protocol Security Summary

# Replace insecure protocols:

# HTTP (port ___) → HTTPS (port ___)
# FTP (port ___) → FTPS (port ___) or SFTP (port ___)
# Telnet (port ___) → SSH (port ___)
# SMTP (port ___) → SMTP+TLS (port ___)
# POP3 (port ___) → POP3S (port ___)
# IMAP (port ___) → IMAPS (port ___)
# LDAP (port ___) → LDAPS (port ___)
# SNMP v1/v2 → SNMP___ (same port, different version)

solution:
# Common Network Protocols Complete Exercise - COMPLETE SOLUTION

## SECTION 1: Protocol Categories Overview

# Eight main protocol categories:
# 1. Application Services: HTTP, HTTPS, FTP, SFTP, TFTP
# 2. Email: SMTP, POP3, IMAP
# 3. Network Services: DNS, DHCP, NTP
# 4. Remote Access: SSH, Telnet, RDP, VNC
# 5. Directory Services: LDAP, Kerberos
# 6. Network Management: SNMP, Syslog
# 7. File Sharing: SMB, NFS
# 8. Voice/Video: SIP, RTP, H.323


## SECTION 2: HTTP - HyperText Transfer Protocol

# Port: 80
# Protocol: TCP (TCP/UDP)
# Security: None (none/encrypted)

# Characteristics:
# - Request-response protocol
# - Stateless (each request independent)
# - Methods: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE

# Status codes:
# 200: OK
# 404: Not Found
# 500: Server Error

# When to use:
# Answer: Internal applications, development (never for sensitive data)


## SECTION 3: HTTPS - HTTP Secure

# Port: 443
# Protocol: TCP (TCP/UDP)
# Security: TLS/SSL encryption

# Three main benefits:
# 1. Encrypts all HTTP traffic
# 2. Server authentication via certificates
# 3. Protects against eavesdropping and tampering

# Certificate components:
# - Public key
# - Issued to: Domain name
# - Issued by: Certificate Authority (CA)
# - Validity period

# When to use:
# Answer: All modern websites, especially those handling sensitive information


## SECTION 4: FTP - File Transfer Protocol

# Port 20: Data connection (TCP)
# Port 21: Control connection (TCP)
# Security: None (credentials and data in clear text)

# Two modes:

# Active FTP:
# - Client connects to server port 21
# - Server connects back to client
# - Problem: Client firewall may block incoming connection

# Passive FTP:
# - Client initiates both connections
# - Solution: Firewall-friendly

# When to use:
# Answer: Legacy systems, internal networks (not secure for Internet)


## SECTION 5: FTPS and SFTP

# FTPS:
# Full name: FTP Secure
# Port (Implicit): 989, 990
# Port (Explicit): 21
# Security: TLS/SSL encryption
# Modes: Implicit or explicit

# SFTP:
# Full name: SSH File Transfer Protocol
# Port: 22
# Protocol: Runs over SSH
# Security: SSH encryption
# Relation to FTPS: Not the same (not/is)
# Modern status: Preferred method for secure file transfer

# Key difference:
# FTPS uses: TLS/SSL encryption
# SFTP uses: SSH encryption


## SECTION 6: TFTP - Trivial FTP

# Port: 69
# Protocol: UDP (TCP/UDP)
# Security: None (none/encrypted)
# Authentication: No (yes/no)

# Characteristics:
# - Minimal overhead
# - No directory listing
# - No authentication

# Three common use cases:
# 1. Router/switch configuration backups
# 2. PXE network booting
# 3. Firmware updates on embedded devices

# When to use:
# Answer: Network device configs, PXE boot, firmware updates (internal networks only)


## SECTION 7: SMTP - Simple Mail Transfer Protocol

# Port 25: Server-to-server relay
# Port 587: Client submission with TLS
# Protocol: TCP (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Sending email (sending/receiving)
# Security: Optional (STARTTLS on port 587)

# SMTP process:
# Client → Mail Server (Port 587): Submit email
# Mail Server → Recipient Server (Port 25): Relay email

# Five SMTP commands:
# 1. HELO: Hello
# 2. MAIL FROM: Sender address
# 3. RCPT TO: Recipient address
# 4. DATA: Message content
# 5. QUIT: End session


## SECTION 8: POP3 - Post Office Protocol v3

# Port (plain): 110
# Port (secure): 995 (POP3S)
# Purpose: Download email from server
# Security: Optional SSL/TLS

# Characteristics:
# - Download-and-delete model
# - Email removed from server after download (typically)
# - Single-device access pattern
# - Simple protocol (simple/complex)
# - Limited folder support (limited/full)

# Five POP3 commands:
# 1. USER: Username
# 2. PASS: Password
# 3. LIST: List messages
# 4. RETR: Retrieve message
# 5. DELE: Delete message

# When to use:
# Answer: Single-device email access, offline email storage


## SECTION 9: IMAP - Internet Message Access Protocol

# Port (plain): 143
# Port (secure): 993 (IMAPS)
# Purpose: Access email on server
# Security: Optional SSL/TLS

# Characteristics:
# - Email stays on server
# - Multi-device synchronization
# - Folder management
# - Partial message downloads
# - Search capabilities
# - More complex than POP3 (complex/simple)


## SECTION 10: IMAP vs POP3 Comparison

# Email location:
# IMAP: Server
# POP3: Client

# Multi-device support:
# IMAP: Yes (yes/no)
# POP3: No (yes/no)

# Folder support:
# IMAP: Full support
# POP3: Limited support

# Storage usage:
# IMAP: Server storage used
# POP3: Client storage used

# Modern preference:
# Answer: IMAP is preferred for modern email access


## SECTION 11: DNS - Domain Name System

# Port: 53
# Protocols: UDP for queries, TCP for zone transfers
# Purpose: Resolve domain names to IP addresses
# Security: DNSSEC available

# Characteristics:
# - Hierarchical distributed database
# - Uses caching to improve performance
# - Multiple record types


## SECTION 12: DNS Record Types

# A record:
# Maps to: IPv4 address (IPv4/IPv6)
# Example: example.com → 192.0.2.1

# AAAA record:
# Maps to: IPv6 address (IPv4/IPv6)
# Example: example.com → 2001:db8::1

# CNAME record:
# Purpose: Canonical name (alias)
# Example: www → example.com

# MX record:
# Purpose: Mail exchange
# Example: mail.example.com (priority 10)

# PTR record:
# Purpose: Reverse lookup (IP to name)
# Direction: Reverse DNS

# NS record:
# Purpose: Name server

# TXT record:
# Purpose: Text records
# Uses: SPF, DKIM, domain verification


## SECTION 13: DNS Query Process

# Four steps:
# 1. Client checks local cache
# 2. Queries configured DNS server (recursive resolver)
# 3. Recursive resolver queries:
#    - Root servers →
#    - TLD servers →
#    - Authoritative servers
# 4. Result cached and returned to client


## SECTION 14: DHCP - Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol

# Port (server): 67
# Port (client): 68
# Protocol: UDP (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Automatic IP address assignment
# Security: None (can be secured with DHCP snooping)

# Four things DHCP provides:
# 1. IP address
# 2. Subnet mask
# 3. Default gateway
# 4. DNS servers

# Assignment type: Lease-based (temporary)


## SECTION 15: DHCP DORA Process

# Step 1 - Discover:
# Client: Broadcasts "I need an IP"
# Method: Broadcast (broadcast/unicast)

# Step 2 - Offer:
# Server: Offers IP address
# Method: Unicast or broadcast

# Step 3 - Request:
# Client: Requests offered IP
# Method: Broadcast (broadcast/unicast)

# Step 4 - Acknowledge:
# Server: Confirms assignment
# Method: Unicast or broadcast


## SECTION 16: DHCP Lease Management

# Default lease time: Often 24 hours to 7 days

# Renewal timing:
# - T1: Client renews at 50% of lease time
# - T2: If renewal fails, rebinding at 87.5% of lease time

# Client can: Voluntarily release IP

# Key DHCP options:
# Option 1: Subnet mask
# Option 3: Default gateway (router)
# Option 6: DNS servers
# Option 66: TFTP server (for PXE boot)


## SECTION 17: NTP - Network Time Protocol

# Port: 123
# Protocol: UDP (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Clock synchronization
# Security: NTPsec, authentication

# Hierarchical system:
# - Stratum 0: Reference clocks (atomic, GPS)
# - Stratum 1: Servers directly connected to Stratum 0
# - Stratum 2-15: Further downstream
# - Stratum 16: Unsynchronized

# Three reasons NTP is critical:
# 1. Log correlation
# 2. Kerberos authentication (±5 min tolerance)
# 3. Certificate validation

# Four public NTP servers:
# 1. time.nist.gov
# 2. pool.ntp.org
# 3. time.google.com
# 4. time.windows.com


## SECTION 18: SSH - Secure Shell

# Port: 22
# Protocol: TCP (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Secure remote access and file transfer
# Security: Strong encryption
# Replaces: Telnet (insecure protocol)

# Three authentication methods:
# 1. Password: Username and password
# 2. Public key: More secure, no password needed
# 3. Certificate: PKI-based authentication

# Four SSH uses:
# 1. Remote command-line access
# 2. Secure file transfer (SFTP, SCP)
# 3. Port forwarding (tunneling)
# 4. Remote command execution

# Common implementations:
# - OpenSSH
# - PuTTY


## SECTION 19: Telnet

# Port: 23
# Protocol: TCP (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Remote terminal access
# Security: None (all data in clear text)

# Security risk:
# - Credentials visible to packet sniffers
# - All data unencrypted
# - Legacy protocol

# Two valid uses:
# 1. Testing port connectivity (telnet host port)
# 2. Legacy device management (internal networks only)

# Modern replacement:
# Answer: SSH (port 22)


## SECTION 20: RDP - Remote Desktop Protocol

# Port: 3389
# Protocol: TCP (TCP/UDP)
# Vendor: Microsoft
# Purpose: Windows remote desktop access
# Type: Graphical remote control
# Security: Encryption available (TLS)
# Built into: Windows

# Features:
# - Sound redirection
# - Clipboard sharing
# - Printer redirection
# - Multi-monitor support
# - Network Level Authentication (NLA)

# Five RDP security practices:
# 1. Use Network Level Authentication
# 2. Enable TLS encryption
# 3. Use strong passwords or certificates
# 4. Implement account lockout policies
# 5. Consider VPN for Internet access


## SECTION 21: VNC - Virtual Network Computing

# Port: 5900 + display number
# Protocol: TCP (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Platform-independent remote desktop
# Security: Usually weak (encryption varies)

# Characteristics:
# - Cross-platform (Windows, Linux, macOS)
# - Multiple implementations (RealVNC, TightVNC, etc.)
# - Generally less secure than RDP
# - Can tunnel over SSH for security

# Port calculation:
# Display :0 → Port 5900
# Display :1 → Port 5901
# Display :2 → Port 5902


## SECTION 22: LDAP - Lightweight Directory Access Protocol

# Port (plain): 389
# Port (secure): 636 (LDAPS)
# Protocol: TCP (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Access and maintain directory services
# Security: Optional TLS (LDAPS)

# Characteristics:
# - Hierarchical directory structure
# - Used by Active Directory
# - Store user accounts, groups, computers
# - Authentication and authorization

# LDAP structure example:
# dc=example,dc=com (domain)
#   └── ou=Users (organizational unit)
#        └── cn=John Doe (common name)

# Five LDAP operations:
# 1. Bind: Authenticate
# 2. Search: Query
# 3. Add: Create entry
# 4. Modify: Update entry
# 5. Delete: Remove entry


## SECTION 23: Kerberos

# Port: 88
# Protocol: TCP/UDP (both)
# Purpose: Network authentication protocol
# Security: Strong authentication
# Used by: Active Directory

# Characteristics:
# - Ticket-based authentication
# - Single Sign-On (SSO)
# - Mutual authentication (client and server verify each other)
# - Time-sensitive: Requires synchronized clocks (±5 min tolerance)

# Three Kerberos components:
# - KDC: Key Distribution Center (Domain Controller)
# - TGT: Ticket Granting Ticket
# - Realm: Kerberos domain (EXAMPLE.COM)


## SECTION 24: Kerberos Process

# Six steps:
# 1. Client → KDC: Request Ticket Granting Ticket (TGT)
# 2. KDC → Client: TGT (encrypted with user password)
# 3. Client → KDC: Request service ticket using TGT
# 4. KDC → Client: Service ticket
# 5. Client → Server: Present service ticket
# 6. Server → Client: Grant access


## SECTION 25: RADIUS

# Full name: Remote Authentication Dial-In User Service
# Port (auth): 1812
# Port (accounting): 1813
# Protocol: UDP (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Centralized AAA (Authentication, Authorization, Accounting)
# Security: Shared secret, MD5

# Encryption:
# RADIUS encrypts: Password only (not entire packet)

# Three common use cases:
# 1. 802.1X wireless authentication
# 2. VPN authentication
# 3. Network device management


## SECTION 26: TACACS+

# Full name: Terminal Access Controller Access-Control System Plus
# Port: 49
# Protocol: TCP (TCP/UDP)
# Vendor: Cisco (proprietary)
# Purpose: AAA protocol
# Security: Encrypts entire packet

# Key advantage over RADIUS:
# TACACS+ encrypts: Entire packet
# RADIUS encrypts: Password only

# Protocol reliability:
# TACACS+ uses: TCP (more reliable)
# RADIUS uses: UDP (less reliable)

# Typical use case:
# Answer: Cisco network device administration


## SECTION 27: TACACS+ vs RADIUS Comparison

# Encryption:
# TACACS+: Full packet
# RADIUS: Password only

# Protocol:
# TACACS+: TCP (port 49)
# RADIUS: UDP (ports 1812, 1813)

# AAA separation:
# TACACS+: Yes (yes/no)
# RADIUS: No (yes/no)

# Vendor:
# TACACS+: Cisco proprietary
# RADIUS: Open standard

# Best for:
# TACACS+: Device administration
# RADIUS: Network access


## SECTION 28: SNMP - Simple Network Management Protocol

# Port (queries): 161
# Port (traps): 162
# Protocol: UDP (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Network device monitoring and management
# Model: Manager-agent model

# Three SNMP versions:
# SNMPv1: Original, community strings (plain text)
# SNMPv2c: Improved performance, still community strings
# SNMPv3: Authentication and encryption (use this!)

# Five SNMP operations:
# 1. GET: Retrieve single value
# 2. GET-NEXT: Retrieve next value
# 3. GET-BULK: Retrieve multiple values
# 4. SET: Modify configuration
# 5. TRAP: Unsolicited alert from agent

# MIB:
# Full name: Management Information Base
# Contains: Database of manageable objects
# Identifier: OID (Object Identifier)


## SECTION 29: Syslog

# Port: 514
# Protocol: UDP (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Centralized logging
# Security: None (can use TLS)

# Eight severity levels (0-7):
# Level 0: Emergency (system unusable)
# Level 1: Alert (immediate action required)
# Level 2: Critical (critical condition)
# Level 3: Error (error condition)
# Level 4: Warning (warning condition)
# Level 5: Notice (normal but significant)
# Level 6: Informational (informational message)
# Level 7: Debug (debug-level message)

# Syslog message format:
# <Priority>Timestamp Hostname Process[PID]: Message


## SECTION 30: SMB - Server Message Block

# Port: 445
# Legacy ports: 137-139
# Protocol: TCP (TCP/UDP)
# OS: Windows file and printer sharing
# Old name: CIFS (older versions)
# Security: SMB3+ encrypted

# Three SMB versions:
# SMB1: Obsolete, major security issues (WannaCry), disable it!
# SMB2: Windows Vista+, significant improvements
# SMB3: Windows 8+, encryption, better performance

# Use:
# - Network drive mapping (Z:)
# - Printer sharing

# Security note:
# Answer: Disable SMB1 due to security vulnerabilities


## SECTION 31: NFS - Network File System

# Port: 2049
# Protocol: TCP/UDP (both)
# OS: Unix/Linux file sharing
# Purpose: Mount remote directories locally
# Security: NFSv4 has Kerberos support

# Characteristics:
# - Unix/Linux native
# - Transparent file access
# - Versions: NFSv3 (common), NFSv4 (modern)

# NFS vs SMB:
# NFS: Unix/Linux native
# SMB: Windows native
# Both: Can work cross-platform


## SECTION 32: SIP - Session Initiation Protocol

# Port (unencrypted): 5060
# Port (encrypted): 5061 (TLS)
# Protocol: UDP/TCP (both)
# Purpose: VoIP call setup and management
# Type: Signaling protocol (not voice transport)

# Functions:
# - Call setup, modification, teardown
# - Video conferencing
# - Instant messaging
# - Works with RTP for actual media

# Five SIP messages:
# 1. INVITE: Initiate call
# 2. ACK: Confirm invitation
# 3. BYE: End call
# 4. CANCEL: Cancel pending invitation
# 5. REGISTER: Register with SIP server


## SECTION 33: RTP - Real-time Transport Protocol

# Port: Dynamic (typically 16384-32767)
# Protocol: UDP (TCP/UDP)
# Purpose: Audio/video delivery
# Security: SRTP (Secure RTP)

# Characteristics:
# - Delivers audio and video streams
# - Works with SIP (signaling)
# - Low latency
# - Sequence numbers for ordering
# - Timestamp for synchronization
# - Does not guarantee delivery (UDP)

# Relationship:
# SIP handles: Signaling
# RTP handles: Media delivery


## SECTION 34: Protocol Security Summary

# Replace insecure protocols:

# HTTP (port 80) → HTTPS (port 443)
# FTP (port 21) → FTPS (port 990) or SFTP (port 22)
# Telnet (port 23) → SSH (port 22)
# SMTP (port 25) → SMTP+TLS (port 587)
# POP3 (port 110) → POP3S (port 995)
# IMAP (port 143) → IMAPS (port 993)
# LDAP (port 389) → LDAPS (port 636)
# SNMP v1/v2 → SNMPv3 (same port, different version)


## SECTION 35: Scenario 1 - Web Server Setup
# Setting up public web server

# Question 1: Which protocol?
# Answer: HTTPS (never HTTP for public servers)

# Question 2: What port?
# Answer: 443

# Question 3: What security needed?
# Answer: TLS/SSL certificate

# Question 4: What does certificate provide?
# Answer: Encryption and server authentication


## SECTION 36: Scenario 2 - Email System
# Setting up company email system

# Question 1: Protocol for sending email?
# Answer: SMTP (port 587 for client submission)

# Question 2: Protocol for receiving (modern)?
# Answer: IMAP (port 993 with SSL/TLS)

# Question 3: Why IMAP over POP3?
# Answer: IMAP keeps email on server, supports multi-device sync

# Question 4: Secure ports to use?
# SMTP: 587
# IMAP: 993


## SECTION 37: Scenario 3 - File Transfer Security
# Need secure file transfer to remote server

# Question 1: Most secure protocol?
# Answer: SFTP (SSH File Transfer Protocol)

# Question 2: Port?
# Answer: 22

# Question 3: Why not FTP?
# Answer: FTP sends credentials in clear text

# Question 4: Why not FTPS?
# Answer: SFTP is preferred because it runs over SSH (single connection, easier for firewalls)


## SECTION 38: Scenario 4 - Remote Server Management
# Managing Linux servers remotely

# Question 1: Best protocol?
# Answer: SSH (port 22)

# Question 2: Why not Telnet?
# Answer: Telnet is unencrypted (no encryption)

# Question 3: SSH authentication methods (2 secure options)?
# 1. Public key authentication
# 2. Certificate authentication

# Question 4: Additional SSH features?
# Answer: Port forwarding (tunneling), file transfer (SFTP)


## SECTION 39: Scenario 5 - Network Monitoring
# Monitoring 100 network devices

# Question 1: Protocol for monitoring?
# Answer: SNMP (Simple Network Management Protocol)

# Question 2: Ports?
# Queries: Port 161
# Traps: Port 162

# Question 3: Which version?
# Answer: SNMPv3 (encrypted and authenticated)

# Question 4: For centralized logging?
# Answer: Syslog (port 514)


## SECTION 40: FINAL REVIEW - Port Numbers

# Fill in all port numbers:
# HTTP: 80
# HTTPS: 443
# FTP: 20, 21
# SSH/SFTP: 22
# Telnet: 23
# SMTP (relay): 25
# SMTP (submission): 587
# DNS: 53
# DHCP Server: 67
# DHCP Client: 68
# TFTP: 69
# POP3: 110
# POP3S: 995
# NTP: 123
# IMAP: 143
# IMAPS: 993
# SNMP: 161, 162
# Syslog: 514
# LDAP: 389
# LDAPS: 636
# Kerberos: 88
# RADIUS: 1812, 1813
# TACACS+: 49
# RDP: 3389
# SMB: 445
# NFS: 2049
# SIP: 5060, 5061

# CRITICAL: Memorize these ports for the exam!
hints: Web: HTTP (80, insecure) vs HTTPS (443, TLS/SSL encrypted)
File Transfer: FTP (20/21, insecure) vs FTPS (989/990) vs SFTP (22 over SSH, preferred)
TFTP (69, UDP): No authentication, used for PXE boot and router configs
Email sending: SMTP port 25 (server-to-server) or 587 (client submission with TLS)
Email receiving: POP3 (110, download-and-delete) vs IMAP (143, server-based, multi-device)
Secure email: POP3S (995), IMAPS (993), SMTP with TLS (587)
DNS (53): UDP for queries, TCP for zone transfers; A (IPv4), AAAA (IPv6), MX (mail), CNAME (alias)
DHCP (67/68, UDP): DORA process (Discover, Offer, Request, Acknowledge)
NTP (123, UDP): Time synchronization, Stratum 0-15, critical for Kerberos (±5 min)
Remote access: SSH (22, encrypted) replaces Telnet (23, insecure clear text)
RDP (3389, Microsoft Windows) vs VNC (5900+, cross-platform, less secure)
LDAP (389) vs LDAPS (636): Directory services, used by Active Directory
Kerberos (88): Ticket-based authentication, SSO, requires time sync ±5 min
RADIUS (1812/1813, UDP) vs TACACS+ (49, TCP): TACACS+ encrypts full packet, Cisco
SNMP (161 queries, 162 traps): Use SNMPv3 for encryption, avoid v1/v2c
SMB (445, Windows) vs NFS (2049, Unix/Linux): Disable SMB1 (security)
VoIP: SIP (5060/5061) for signaling, RTP (dynamic UDP) for media delivery
Always use encrypted versions: HTTPS, SFTP, SSH, IMAPS, POP3S, LDAPS, SNMPv3

testCases.description: Knows HTTP port 80 and HTTPS port 443
testCases.validation: assert '80' in code and '443' in code

testCases.description: Understands SFTP (port 22) is preferred over FTP (20/21) for security
testCases.validation: assert '22' in code or 'sftp' in code.lower() or 'ssh' in code.lower()

testCases.description: Knows SMTP ports 25 (relay) and 587 (submission with TLS)
testCases.validation: assert '25' in code and '587' in code
assert 'imap' in code.lower() or 'pop3' in code.lower()

testCases.description: Knows DNS port 53 and DHCP ports 67/68
testCases.validation: assert '53' in code and ('67' in code or '68' in code)

testCases.description: Understands DHCP DORA process (Discover, Offer, Request, Acknowledge)
testCases.validation: assert 'dora' in code.lower() or 'discover' in code.lower()

testCases.description: Knows SSH (22) is secure replacement for Telnet (23)
testCases.validation: assert 'ssh' in code.lower() or 'telnet' in code.lower()
assert '161' in code or '162' in code or 'snmp' in code.lower()

testCases.description: Knows Kerberos (88) requires time sync and RADIUS uses ports 1812/1813
testCases.validation: assert 'kerberos' in code.lower() or 'radius' in code.lower() or '88' in code

testCases.description: Understands protocol security (encrypted vs unencrypted versions)
testCases.validation: assert 'https' in code.lower() or 'secure' in code.lower() or 'encrypt' in code.lower()
